[Blum Says He’s Done Suing Law Firms as Winston Yields on DEI](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/blum-says-hes-done-suing-law-firms-as-winston-yields-on-dei) [Bloomberg Law]

Earlier: [The Slippery Slope Of Ending Affirmative Action Has Moved On To Its Next Target: Women And ‘Proxies For Diversity’](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/the-slippery-slope-of-ending-affirmative-action-has-moved-on-to-its-next-target-women-and-proxies-for-diversity/)

Chris Williams became a social media manager and assistant editor for Above the Law in June 2021. Prior to joining the staff, he moonlighted as a minor Memelord™ in the Facebook group [Law School Memes for Edgy T14s](https://www.facebook.com/photo/?fbid=10222912314148913&set=p.10222912314148913&opaqueCursor=AboVBPzRKh4loie1LupyI7ltSvsaUWxURlMk_338xXb_BPhzMNPHbWfVDUsOyUH1mfvHQ4Bsipef989J-V0OyqhMZzHPafTw49vttxDh_no8xymRSSUssmh47qTzHAc13R0wzk8nPhgSylnSAYcBNbHjYDqZDqy5r0f7PwzCZw9T-0cakKMIin3XI0O8R5H5OJGAu4kJjGPAoZpgL6woU9lwoHiAjxAwAlpmdlyt6vHLJ1TVn2srkC3G4qBW5ANthJ_YNT3BUPCu2vu1ZIxiqYwXGLfMIxQR4cllUaB0Cja74ln1FHs3n-xyHe6MDtxln0-F4QJchox9nCaivB_xmSxw3FduERhPebhWj1MKJ20jeucGZ64jY6DdUn2d87dVgNlFE5qHvNEtfMpoEKx1096oFfqbZ9s71YVsbXxLIsRiiW54eLp4R7z3WHAKu8v8xeLIZt86UVU1iOaSlJ0n5tT3_VonQT6n2F0sIUSLY272cI-yjWxaUIr0Qj-1NQDFFcn9dkq8pYV2-o0M3LK2Qhr9LKt-Bk4MTGUZCkb4Kw6mgDmRCux3nhJqd2hdLd8LgTA).  He endured Missouri long enough to graduate from Washington University in St. Louis School of Law. He is a former boatbuilder who cannot swim, [a published author on critical race theory, philosophy, and humor](https://www.academia.edu/33296970/Lets_Be_Frank_Parrhesia_and_the_Black_Comedic_Tradition), and has a love for cycling that occasionally annoys his peers. You can reach him by email at [cwilliams@abovethelaw.com](mailto:cwilliams@abovethelaw.com) and by tweet at [@WritesForRent](https://twitter.com/WritesForRent).

# More Law Firms Should Participate In Sports Leagues
## Not only can such teams increase connections between coworkers, they can forge connections with colleagues within the legal community as well.
By [Jordan Rothman](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jordanrothman/)  
onDecember 10, 2021 at 7:29 PMDecember 10, 2021 at 3:46 PM
7
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/more-law-firms-should-participate-in-sports-leagues/&text=More%20Law%20Firms%20Should%20Participate%20In%20Sports%20Leagues)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/more-law-firms-should-participate-in-sports-leagues/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/more-law-firms-should-participate-in-sports-leagues/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

Most lawyers do not get too many opportunities to bond with their coworkers outside of the office. Sure, many law firms host annual holiday parties and other similar gatherings outside of the four walls of an office, but such events can be stressful, and it might be difficult for attorneys and staff to unwind at such functions and connect on a deeper level. Some law firms participate in softball leagues, and perhaps other sports leagues, so attorneys and staff have the chance to bond while participating in a nonlegal activity. Participating in such leagues is difficult in the COVID-19 era, and it seems like such participation has been on the decline in recent years. Nevertheless, more law firms should participate in such leagues for a variety of reasons.

The first time I ever heard about a law firm softball league was when my older brother (and law partner) played for a law firm softball league when he was a summer law clerk at a law firm. I remember him saying that this was a good way to connect with management at the firm, and I distinctly recall him wearing his dirt-stained softball shirt and baseball cap when he got home from work at night that summer. I kept this in the back of my mind when I was a summer associate, and I made sure that I would participate in my firm’s softball league if the firm at which I worked had a team.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
I am not at all good at softball. Some vision issues make it almost impossible for me to reliably catch or hit a ball. As a result, I was a little hesitant to join the firm’s softball team. However, summer associates are usually rewarded if they go above and beyond to connect with people at the law firm, so I cast any fears aside and wholeheartedly participated in the firm’s softball team.

Going to the softball games was an enriching and unique experience. I got to know the members of the firm’s softball team better than people I just knew around the office since it is much easier to open up to people when you are outside of a workplace. In addition, it is much easier to make memories and forge a deeper connection with people while participating in softball than while working on any of the legal tasks we needed to complete in the office. Moreover, many law firms participate in softball leagues against other law firms and such participation is a great way to connect with colleagues who may work at another law firm.

After each softball game, the firm would pay for us to have an after-game dinner at a local sports bar. This was another chance for all of us to unwind and discuss what happened during the game. Also, this was a way for me to score free dinner, which was a plus since I was still a poor law student at the time!

When attorneys and staff participate in sports leagues like softball, it is easy for people to forget about their roles at an office and just focus on the task at hand. It doesn’t matter if someone is a partner, associate, or staff, everyone was there to have fun. Fortunately, most of the time, the softball games that my firm participated in were rather chill, and when I went up to bat, people cheered like hell for me even though I almost always invariably struck out.

### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Of course, it is important to keep considerations in mind when law firms field a softball team. For one, it is important to recognize that people of different genders and ability levels should be able to participate in games. This is usually fairly easy to accommodate, especially if people are participating in a noncompetitive softball league. Of course, some of the softball leagues I hear law firms participate in are super competitive, and it is unfortunate if people are excluded from participating because of their ability. In addition, it is important to ensure that even if the team performs poorly, everyone still has a positive experience (which is usually easier to do when there is an after-game dinner from my personal experience).

The only time I ever worked at a firm that had a softball team was when I was in Biglaw. Of course, a firm needs to have a large number of employees and resources to field a team, and this might be a reason why Biglaw shops are more likely to have softball teams. However, it seems from my anecdotal experience that even before COVID-19, softball and other similar leagues among law firms were on the decline.

Nevertheless, more law firms should consider fielding softball or other sports teams for all of the benefits shops can realize from this participation. Not only can such teams increase connections between coworkers, they can forge connections with colleagues within the legal community as well.

Jordan Rothman is a partner of [The Rothman Law Firm](http://www.rothmanlawyer.com/), a full-service New York and New Jersey law firm. He is also the founder of [Student Debt Diaries](https://studentdebtdiaries.com/), a website discussing how he paid off his student loans. You can reach Jordan through email at [jordan@rothmanlawyer.com](mailto:jordan@rothmanlawyer.com?subject=Your%20ATL%20column).

# Harvard Joins Columbia In Moving Recruiting To Next Year
## A big domino just fell.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onMarch 31, 2020 at 4:46 PMMarch 31, 2020 at 7:14 PM
156
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/harvard-joins-columbia-in-moving-recruiting-to-next-year/&text=Harvard%20Joins%20Columbia%20In%20Moving%20Recruiting%20To%20Next%20Year)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/harvard-joins-columbia-in-moving-recruiting-to-next-year/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/harvard-joins-columbia-in-moving-recruiting-to-next-year/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Columbia already saw the writing on the wall and moved its on-campus interview process to January 2021. No one knows for sure when this whole thing will be over, half of the transcripts students will have to show employers will be a bunch of “Pass” grades, and by the end of the summer, a lot of firms are just going to be taking stock of where their layoffs and furloughs have left them, so why persist in the delusion that firms will be hiring in August? And from what we’ve been hearing, other schools have also gone the Columbia route with at least Duke and Georgetown postponing early interview time as well (UPDATE: Yale and Stanford have announced delays as well, but they haven’t yet settled on 2021 like Columbia and Harvard have).

Apparently, Harvard will become the first “HYS” school to put off early interviews. EIP, the Early Interview Program, will move to January 2021 according to a message sent to Above the Law:

Today, we write with an important update on EIP and the upcoming law firm recruiting season. After numerous discussions with students and employers, we have decided to move EIP Week to January 2021 and to suspend EIP Preview for this recruiting season. We will provide additional information about EIP in the coming weeks as we flesh out the details of our program.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
While other schools moved first, Harvard’s decision likely opens the floodgates on recruiting changes. Biglaw firms aren’t going to fill their future classes without talking Harvard students, so there’s not going to be any appetite to gather everyone from Chicago in August only to tell them to expect a callback in February. By Friday, the rest of the T14 will almost certainly have pushed on-campus recruiting to match whatever Harvard’s doing.

I guess our on-campus interview shopping guide is going to have to be a lot more winter weather-centric…

# Elite Biglaw Firm Goes Out Of Its Way To Reassure First-Year Associates Their Jobs Are Safe
## Working for Milbank? You don't have to worry.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onApril 13, 2023 at 6:33 PMApril 14, 2023 at 11:46 AM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/04/milbank-start-date/&text=Elite%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Goes%20Out%20Of%20Its%20Way%20To%20Reassure%20First-Year%20Associates%20Their%20Jobs%20Are%20Safe)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/04/milbank-start-date/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/04/milbank-start-date/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Soon-to-be first-year associates have some reasons to be nervous. With graduation in May, student loans start coming due by November so making sure they start their lucrative Biglaw jobs before then is incredibly important. And some firms — [Cooley](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/04/after-layoffs-last-year-cooley-delays-start-date-for-first-year-associates/) and [Gunderson](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/gunderson-deferred-associates-start-work/), so far — have pushed back the expected start date of their incoming classes. So, it might be nerve-racking if you haven’t heard from your perspective employer.

The folks at Milbank understand that anxiety. So they’ve sent an email, available in full [on the next page](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/04/milbank-start-date/2/), assuring their incoming class that Milbank will *not* be delaying its start date. As initially set, first years will start at the firm on September 18th.

It might seem like non-news, since the status quo remains in place, but it reflects an understanding of what folks are going through. Doom and gloom is being forecast across the industry with legal commentators speculating which other firms [will follow Cooley](https://www.law.com/2023/04/11/cooley-deferred-its-incoming-class-will-others-jump-on-the-bandwagon-or-hold-the-line/) with their own delays. Milbank knows that, and wants to make sure their people know they don’t have to worry. Classy move, all the way around

# Few Leads Have Emerged In Case Of Slain Biglaw Partner
## Police have called the murder of James Gilliland a 'mystery.'
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onNovember 3, 2016 at 2:00 PMNovember 3, 2016 at 2:07 PM
10
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/few-leads-have-emerged-in-case-of-slain-biglaw-partner/&text=Few%20Leads%20Have%20Emerged%20In%20Case%20Of%20Slain%20Biglaw%20Partner)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/few-leads-have-emerged-in-case-of-slain-biglaw-partner/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/few-leads-have-emerged-in-case-of-slain-biglaw-partner/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Jim Gilliland

The murder that has shocked the small Northern California city of El Cerrito and the Biglaw community continues to stump investigators. Calling the killing of [Kilpatrick Townsend partner](http://www.kilpatricktownsend.com/en/Who_We_Are/Professionals/G/GillilandJrJamesG14932.aspx) James Gilliland a “mystery,” police have not revealed any leads in the case.

Police have said they do not believe robbery or his work at the Biglaw firm are motives behind the murder, as [reported by](http://www.sfgate.com/crime/article/No-evidence-slain-SF-attorney-was-robbed-in-El-10534761.php) SF Gate:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Detectives have uncovered no evidence thus far that James Gilliland Jr., 62, was robbed during the Thursday night shooting or that his slaying was connected to his work as an intellectual property attorney, said Lt. Robert De La Campa of the El Cerrito Police Department.

De La Campa said Gilliland’s wallet and cell phone were still on his body when he was found shot to death.

Police are asking anyone with information about this tragic killing to contact them at (510) 215-4400 or email [investigations@ci.el-cerrito.ca.us](mailto:investigations@ci.el-cerrito.ca.us).

[No evidence slain SF attorney was robbed in El Cerrito shooting](http://www.sfgate.com/crime/article/No-evidence-slain-SF-attorney-was-robbed-in-El-10534761.php) [SF Gate]

# The Biglaw Firms Potentially Caught In The Cohen Raid
## Which firms are connected to the controversial attorney?
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onApril 17, 2018 at 2:15 PMApril 20, 2018 at 11:08 AM
48
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/the-biglaw-firms-potentially-caught-in-the-cohen-raid/&text=The%20Biglaw%20Firms%20Potentially%20Caught%20In%20The%20Cohen%20Raid)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/the-biglaw-firms-potentially-caught-in-the-cohen-raid/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/the-biglaw-firms-potentially-caught-in-the-cohen-raid/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Michael Cohen (Photo by Mark Wilson/Getty Images)

Discovery nerds — and political junkies — are having a field day with the materials seized by the FBI’s raid of Trump Organization attorney Michael Cohen. S.D.N.Y.’s Judge Kimba Wood [has ruled over the proceedings](https://www.law.com/2018/04/16/fox-host-hannity-revealed-as-cohens-third-client-as-wood-expresses-confidence-in-feds-filter-team/) with aplomb — revealing Sean Hannity as a client of Michael Cohen and bringing the term “taint team” to living rooms across the nation. But there’s some Biglaw news buried in the details of porn stars, “taint” and payoffs.

Cohen’s legal team, led by McDermott Will & Emery partner Stephen Ryan, wanted, in order of preference, their team or a third party special master to review the seized material for privilege. It was ultimately an unsuccessful attempt to stop the Department of Justice’s filter team (I really can’t say “taint” anymore) from getting the first look at the materials seized in the raid, but the legal team did tell Judge Wood that Biglaw privileged materials may be in the FBI’s haul.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
The first Biglaw firm caught up in the mess is Squire Patton Boggs. Last year the firm announced a [strategic alliance](http://www.law.com/americanlawyer/almID/1202782865269/Squire-Patton-Boggs-Strikes-Alliance-With-Trumps-Lawyer/) with Cohen, but as the heat’s been turned up, they’ve sought to [distance themselves](http://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2018/04/09/after-fbi-raid-squire-says-it-severed-ties-to-trump-lawyer-michael-cohen/). Despite that, Ryan said there was a possibility Squire Patton Boggs’s privileged materials got caught up in the raid, as[ reported by](https://www.law.com/2018/04/16/cohen-claims-morgan-lewis-squire-patton-boggs-records-in-seized-materials/) Law.com:

Ryan’s letter on Monday left open the possibility that Squire Patton Boggs client matters referred by Cohen could have been seized by law enforcement. He claimed that Cohen referred five clients to Squire Patton Boggs and “likely participated in communications with attorneys and clients” of the firm related to these client referrals.

“We are not listing them today and defer to [Squire Patton Boggs] and its clients to assert a privilege claim,” Ryan said.

The prosecution, however, said the chance Squire Patton Boggs’s materials were seized are small. And the firm seems to agree:

A Squire Patton Boggs spokesman said Monday that since Cohen was “never an employee or partner of our firm, and since neither our firm nor any of our clients are involved in the government’s investigation, there is nothing to add to what is already stated” by prosecutors in a [brief last week](http://www.documentcloud.org/documents/4437375-Cohen-Memo.html).

From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
There were other firms’ materials the defense asserted could have been caught in the raid — including Morgan Lewis partner Sheri Dillon, who [rocketed to infamy](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/01/snls-savage-portrayal-of-a-biglaw-partner/) taking the bullet for the Trump administration’s interpretation of the emoluments clause:

Other law firms and lawyers who have advised Cohen and whose documents may be contained in the seized records, said Ryan, include Morgan Lewis tax attorney Sheri Dillon, whose work on behalf of Trump took center stage last year with regard to the president’s family business and his ethical duties and obligations; David Schwartz of New York’s Gerstman Schwartz Malito, Cohen’s attorney in a libel suit against news website BuzzFeed; Brent Blakely, who is representing Cohen in a California suit brought by Stephanie Clifford, the porn star better known as Stormy Daniels; and Michael Sirota and David Bass of Cole Schotz, for trusts and estates and corporate advisory issues. (Cole Schotz has previously advised on Trump business matters.)

In addition to having long range implication for the fate of the American democracy, [the Cohen investigation](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/clown-lawyer-michael-cohen-gonna-learn-today/) is also providing lawyers with lots to gossip about.

Kathryn Rubino is an editor at Above the Law. AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](https://twitter.com/Kathryn1)).

Walgreens announced that it is expanding its specialty pharmacy offerings. They also think Walgreens’ move could lead to greater competition, consolidation, and innovation within the broader pharmacy industry.

# From Courtroom To Newsroom: Camille Vasquez Makes A Newsworthy TV Debut!
## I did not know this is what they meant by a JD advantage.
By [Chris Williams](https://abovethelaw.com/author/cwilliams/)  
onJanuary 9, 2023 at 4:16 PMJanuary 9, 2023 at 3:44 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/from-courtroom-to-newsroom-camille-vasquez-makes-a-newsworthy-tv-debut/&text=From%20Courtroom%20To%20Newsroom:%20Camille%20Vasquez%20Makes%20A%20Newsworthy%20TV%20Debut!)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/from-courtroom-to-newsroom-camille-vasquez-makes-a-newsworthy-tv-debut/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/from-courtroom-to-newsroom-camille-vasquez-makes-a-newsworthy-tv-debut/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Photo by BRENDAN SMIALOWSKI/POOL/AFP via Getty Images)

For some attorneys, one of the worst parts of their job is speaking in public. That isn’t too surprising — while the data supports death as being a primary fear, public speaking is still in the running. Despite that, some lawyers still find a way to thrive in the public eye. So much in fact, they may make take on a side hustle that involves even more public speaking. From Deadline:

[Camille Vasquez](https://deadline.com/tag/camille-vasquez/), who gained notoriety as one of [Johnny Depp](https://deadline.com/tag/johnny-depp/)’s lawyers in his defamation case against ex-wife Amber Heard, has joined [NBC News](https://deadline.com/tag/nbc-news/) as a legal analyst.

Vasquez made her first appearance in the role on [Today](https://deadline.com/tag/today/) on Monday to offer analysis on Bryan Kohberger’s arrest on charges of stabbing four University of Idaho students.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Talk about taking a stab at TV!

Vasquez remains a partner at Brown Rudnick. Here is her NBC News debut:

Camille Vasquez as a legal analyst for [@NBCNews](https://twitter.com/NBCNews?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw) appeared on Today to discuss the Idaho Murders [#Idahohomocides](https://twitter.com/hashtag/Idahohomocides?src=hash&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw) [#CamilleVasquez](https://twitter.com/hashtag/CamilleVasquez?src=hash&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw) [#BryanKohberger](https://twitter.com/hashtag/BryanKohberger?src=hash&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw) [pic.twitter.com/p4ikARjHe9](https://t.co/p4ikARjHe9)

— Jeannie (@jeanniebrichett) [January 9, 2023](https://twitter.com/jeanniebrichett/status/1612490382452920326?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

As stories of her coverage develop, know that you can come to Above the Law to hear more about it. Or you can go to NBC News, then come here. We’d prefer you do the latter.

Chris Williams became a social media manager and assistant editor for Above the Law in June 2021. Prior to joining the staff, he moonlighted as a minor Memelord™ in the Facebook group [Law School Memes for Edgy T14s](https://www.facebook.com/photo/?fbid=10222912314148913&set=p.10222912314148913&opaqueCursor=AboVBPzRKh4loie1LupyI7ltSvsaUWxURlMk_338xXb_BPhzMNPHbWfVDUsOyUH1mfvHQ4Bsipef989J-V0OyqhMZzHPafTw49vttxDh_no8xymRSSUssmh47qTzHAc13R0wzk8nPhgSylnSAYcBNbHjYDqZDqy5r0f7PwzCZw9T-0cakKMIin3XI0O8R5H5OJGAu4kJjGPAoZpgL6woU9lwoHiAjxAwAlpmdlyt6vHLJ1TVn2srkC3G4qBW5ANthJ_YNT3BUPCu2vu1ZIxiqYwXGLfMIxQR4cllUaB0Cja74ln1FHs3n-xyHe6MDtxln0-F4QJchox9nCaivB_xmSxw3FduERhPebhWj1MKJ20jeucGZ64jY6DdUn2d87dVgNlFE5qHvNEtfMpoEKx1096oFfqbZ9s71YVsbXxLIsRiiW54eLp4R7z3WHAKu8v8xeLIZt86UVU1iOaSlJ0n5tT3_VonQT6n2F0sIUSLY272cI-yjWxaUIr0Qj-1NQDFFcn9dkq8pYV2-o0M3LK2Qhr9LKt-Bk4MTGUZCkb4Kw6mgDmRCux3nhJqd2hdLd8LgTA).  He endured Missouri long enough to graduate from Washington University in St. Louis School of Law. He is a former boatbuilder who cannot swim, [a published author on critical race theory, philosophy, and humor](https://www.academia.edu/33296970/Lets_Be_Frank_Parrhesia_and_the_Black_Comedic_Tradition), and has a love for cycling that occasionally annoys his peers. You can reach him by email at [cwilliams@abovethelaw.com](mailto:cwilliams@abovethelaw.com) and by tweet at [@WritesForRent](https://twitter.com/WritesForRent).

# Biglaw's Summer Associate Recruitment Cycle Is The Worst Since The Great Recession
## With a mismatch between talent and legal needs, things are getting a little tricky for law students hoping to work in Biglaw.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 12, 2024 at 1:13 PMMarch 12, 2024 at 12:52 PM
5
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/03/biglaws-summer-associate-recruitment-cycle-is-the-worst-since-the-great-recession/&text=Biglaw’s%20Summer%20Associate%20Recruitment%20Cycle%20Is%20The%20Worst%20Since%20The%20Great%20Recession)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/03/biglaws-summer-associate-recruitment-cycle-is-the-worst-since-the-great-recession/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/03/biglaws-summer-associate-recruitment-cycle-is-the-worst-since-the-great-recession/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

‘Please let me get this job!’

With Biglaw firms pulling back in the race for new talent, student recruitment for summer associate programs has hit a bit of a slump. In fact, according to the National Association for Law Placement (NALP), this was the most underwhelming recruiting cycle since the Great Recession. Yikes.

According to the latest [recruiting figures from NALP](https://www.nalp.org/uploads/PressReleases/NALP_Perspectiveson2023Recruiting_PressRelease.pdf), offer rates for Biglaw summer programs decreased by 19% compared to the last summer’s hiring program. On top of that, just 46% of callback interviews resulted in offers for summer 2024 positions (down six percentage points from last year), which is the lowest offer rate since 2012. With fewer offers on the table, desperation was thick in the air, and it translated to an acceptance rate to those offers of 47% (up six percentage points from last year) — the highest acceptance rate NALP has ever recorded.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
None of this is good news for law students looking for a job in the face of a job market that’s likely to be “challenging.” As noted by [Reuters](https://www.reuters.com/legal/litigation/law-firm-summer-associate-recruiting-hits-11-year-low-2023-2024-03-12/), Nikia L. Gray, NALP’s executive director, wrote in the report that “[f]irms may have growing concerns about absorbing additional new talent if client demand does not increase to keep pace and they continue to carry excess capacity through 2024.”

Enough of the doom and gloom, let’s talk about what happened with 2023’s summer associates. According to NALP, offer rates for Biglaw summer programs remained close to historic highs, with 96% of second-year law students receiving offers for full-time employment as associates after graduation (though it should be noted that his is the lowest offer rate since 2017). Acceptances of those offers matched last year’s all-time high of 89%. That’s all great news, but we can’t help but to wonder if these incoming associates aren’t a little bit worried about their futures given the measures firms took to rightsize recruitment due to excess capacity.

Nevertheless, congratulations to all law students who went through the entry-level recruitment cycle in 2023. We hope that everything works out.

[Drop in Demand for New Talent at Law Firms Results in Softest Recruiting Cycle since the Great Recession](https://www.nalp.org/uploads/PressReleases/NALP_Perspectiveson2023Recruiting_PressRelease.pdf) [NALP]
[Law firm summer associate recruiting hits 11-year low in 2023](https://www.reuters.com/legal/litigation/law-firm-summer-associate-recruiting-hits-11-year-low-2023-2024-03-12/) [Reuters]

# Mastering The Use Of Expert Witnesses
## PLI is assembling a panel of experienced litigators and expert witnesses to demystify some of the most common challenges.
By STEPHANIE WILKINS  
onMay 20, 2022 at 11:17 AMMay 20, 2022 at 10:39 AM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/mastering-the-use-of-expert-witnesses/&text=Mastering%20The%20Use%20Of%20Expert%20Witnesses)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/mastering-the-use-of-expert-witnesses/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/mastering-the-use-of-expert-witnesses/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Expert witnesses play a key role in  litigation practice, and they’ve been garnering press everywhere you look these days — from murder trials and celebrity defamation cases, to the Advisory Committee on Evidence Rules’ recently [proposed rule amendments](https://www.reuters.com/legal/legalindustry/judicial-panel-advances-expert-witness-rule-opposed-by-plaintiffs-bar-2022-05-06/) aimed at curbing the admission of “junk” expert scientific testimony.

Searching for, retaining, using, and examining expert witnesses doesn’t have to be a daunting experience. Mastering the use of these experts can offer critical benefits, particularly in complex litigation.

For its half-day [Expert Witness 2022](https://www.pli.edu/programs/expert-witness?t=live) program, PLI is assembling a panel of experienced litigators and expert witnesses to demystify some of the most common challenges that arise in selecting, preparing, and using experts. Discussion topics will include:

- How to select the right expert for your specific case
- What a Daubert hearing is and how to prepare for and conduct one
- How to defend against a Daubert challenge
- Strategies for deposing an opposing party’s expert
- How to prepare your expert witness to testify at a deposition or a trial
- Tips for mastering direct and cross examination of expert witnesses at trial
Whether you’re new to litigation or a seasoned trial professional, in private practice or part of an in-house team involved in litigation, this program will provide useful insights and practical tools for handling the myriad issues that commonly arise during expert witness preparation and testimony.

[Register today](https://www.pli.edu/programs/expert-witness?t=live) to gain the knowledge you need to master expert witness practice.

 

####Topics
[Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/biglaw/), [In-House Counsel](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/in-house-counsel/), [Litigators](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/litigators/), [On Course](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/on-course/), [On Course Practice](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/on-course-practice/), [Sponsored Content](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/sponsored-content/)

# So Many Documents
## Notes to my (legal) self.
By [Olga V. Mack](https://abovethelaw.com/author/olgamack/)  
onAugust 18, 2023 at 4:16 PMAugust 18, 2023 at 4:06 PM
14
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/so-many-documents/&text=So%20Many%20Documents)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/so-many-documents/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/so-many-documents/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


Olga V. Mack is the VP at [LexisNexis](https://www.lexisnexis.com/) and CEO of [Parley Pro](https://parleypro.com/), a next-generation contract management company that has pioneered online negotiation technology. Olga embraces legal innovation and had dedicated her career to improving and shaping the future of law. She is convinced that the legal profession will emerge even stronger, more resilient, and more inclusive than before by embracing technology. Olga is also an award-winning general counsel, operations professional, startup advisor, public speaker, adjunct professor, and entrepreneur. She founded the [Women Serve on Boards](https://www.womenserveonboards.com/) movement that advocates for women to participate on corporate boards of Fortune 500 companies. She authored [Get on Board: Earning Your Ticket to a Corporate Board Seat](https://www.amazon.com/Get-Board-Earning-Ticket-Corporate/dp/1949991407), [Fundamentals of Smart Contract Security](https://www.amazon.com/Fundamentals-Smart-Contract-Security-Richard-ebook/dp/B07S8YF27G), and  [Blockchain Value: Transforming Business Models, Society, and Communities](https://www.amazon.com/Blockchain-Value-Transforming-Business-Communities/dp/1952538246). She is working on Visual IQ for Lawyers, her next book (ABA 2023). You can follow Olga on Twitter @olgavmack.

# 3 Cybersecurity Risks Your Firm Should Address Today
## How you can safeguard your clients’ data in the cloud.
By FILEVINE AND ABOVE THE LAW  
onAugust 9, 2022 at 3:31 PMAugust 9, 2022 at 3:28 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/3-cybersecurity-risks-your-firm-should-address-today/&text=3%20Cybersecurity%20Risks%20Your%20Firm%20Should%20Address%20Today)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/3-cybersecurity-risks-your-firm-should-address-today/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/3-cybersecurity-risks-your-firm-should-address-today/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
For firms leveraging the cloud for their operations, cybersecurity risk
is abundant, with no sign of slowing down

The need to understand and secure a law firm’s IT operations is clear, but the path toward doing so can be less obvious. 

With that in mind, this white paper from our friends at Filevine aims to describe the sophisticated security controls your firm should utilize to protect your client’s information.

Read on to learn the top three risks to your clients’ data, as well as steps you can take to address these threats today.

# The ABA's Bold Stance Against Losers (Of The Civil War)
## Also, Biglaw's cost-cutting measures continue.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onFebruary 15, 2023 at 1:43 PMFebruary 15, 2023 at 12:34 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/the-abas-bold-stance-against-losers-of-the-civil-war/&text=The%20ABA’s%20Bold%20Stance%20Against%20Losers%20(Of%20The%20Civil%20War))[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/the-abas-bold-stance-against-losers-of-the-civil-war/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/the-abas-bold-stance-against-losers-of-the-civil-war/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
On the latest episode of Thinking Like A Lawyer, Kathryn and Chris ponder the need for a rule [against Confederate flags](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/the-aba-decides-that-courtrooms-shouldnt-still-have-confederate-flags-in-them-also-there-are-courtrooms-with-confederate-flags-still-in-them/) in courtrooms in the UNITED STATES OF AMERICA in the year of our Lord 2023. Speaking of bold stances on things that should be obvious, the American Bar Association would really like [a Supreme Court ethics rule](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/the-aba-has-had-enough-of-the-supreme-court-being-held-unaccountable/), but we know that’s not happening. Plus if you want your full bonus this year[ at Perkins Coie](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/perkins-coie-billable-hours-change/), you’re going to have to bill more hours. Which is a crappy move, but still better [than the layoffs](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/shearman-sterling-associate-layoffs/) slow-moving through Biglaw.

# Referring Work To Lawyers At Your Law Firm Might Be Difficult
## Lawyers at a law firm may not want to assist another attorney who works at the same shop for numerous reasons.
By [Jordan Rothman](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jordanrothman/)  
onMarch 13, 2024 at 11:45 AM
6
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/03/referring-work-to-lawyers-at-your-law-firm-might-be-difficult/&text=Referring%20Work%20To%20Lawyers%20At%20Your%20Law%20Firm%20Might%20Be%20Difficult)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/03/referring-work-to-lawyers-at-your-law-firm-might-be-difficult/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/03/referring-work-to-lawyers-at-your-law-firm-might-be-difficult/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Lawyers often say that among the benefits of working at a larger law firm are the additional resources and practice areas a larger shop might have to better serve clients. Indeed, larger firms can help clients who might have legal needs across different locations and which may involve various areas of the law. However, just because a lawyer works at a law firm that has different practice areas and geographic footprints does not mean that an attorney will be able to marshal those resources well to serve a client.

I first realized this when I was working at a regional law firm around a decade ago. I originated a client that had a legal need in a jurisdiction in which I did not have much experience. However, our law firm had an office in the jurisdiction with attorneys who exclusively practice law in that jurisdiction. I was certain that these lawyers would be able to assist me with any questions I had or possibly even handle the work themselves given that they had more experience in that jurisdiction.

When I called attorneys in our law firm’s office in that jurisdiction, they were not very helpful, and they seemed upset that I was asking them for help. In some instances, they were even outright rude to me. I ended up having to do all of the work on the matter myself, and since I did not have form documents from prior matters in that jurisdiction, I had to reinvent the wheel in some instances even though the other lawyers at my law firm might have had a much easier time performing the work.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Lawyers at a law firm may not want to assist another attorney who works at the same shop for numerous reasons. Perhaps most importantly, the lawyer referred the work might not have any incentive to assist the other attorney. The lawyer who originated the business might receive credit for that client when it is time for promotions or during bonus determinations, but the lawyer performing the work might not receive a similar benefit. Lawyers might not want to go out of their way to help a colleague receive a benefit that they themselves will not realize, especially if they do not know this other attorney well.

In addition, helping another lawyer at a law firm might slow down another attorney and might make it difficult for the other attorney to meet billable hour expectations. Many lawyers work on large accounts, and it is much easier to bill time to larger clients since the lawyer does not need to relearn billing habits, make new client contacts, or spend administrative time on other tasks. When a lawyer needs to spend time on a smaller, new matter, this can take the lawyer away from easier tasks that the lawyers can handle for their typical clients.

Office politics might also make it difficult for a lawyer to help out another lawyer at their law firm with a new matter. Partners are often very territorial about their teams, and they may not want attorneys to work on a given matter rather than other assigned tasks. Moreover, attorneys may not wish to work on a new matter originated by a lawyer because attorneys may be jockeying for a promotion and one lawyer may not want to help support another lawyer in originating new business. In other instances, simple jealously may interfere with a lawyer at a law firm working on a new matter originated by another lawyer, especially if the lawyer doing the work has not originated new business on their own.

All told, there are some benefits of working at larger law firms, and if a lawyer at a shop has significant standing, they can likely refer a new and different matter to a lawyer without too many issues. However, lawyers should keep in mind that just because their firm can handle a matter does not mean that other attorneys at their shop will work on the matter to the best of their abilities.

# Say 'No' To The Tyranny Of 'Yes'
## Once you start learning to say 'no' to the demands of other people, you will find more joy.
By EILEEN LAWRENCE  
onFebruary 23, 2023 at 5:47 PMFebruary 23, 2023 at 4:35 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/say-no-to-the-tyranny-of-yes/&text=Say%20‘No’%20To%20The%20Tyranny%20Of%20‘Yes’)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/say-no-to-the-tyranny-of-yes/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/say-no-to-the-tyranny-of-yes/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

No. Uh-uh. Definitely not.

Ed. note: This is the latest installment in a series of posts on motherhood in the legal profession, in partnership with our friends at [MothersEsquire](https://www.mothersesquire.com/). Welcome Eileen Lawrence to our pages. Click [here](https://www.mothersesquire.com/donate-1) if you’d like to donate to MothersEsquire.

Are you letting your life be ruled by the tyranny of “yes”? The pressure on lawyer moms to say “yes” has been with us from the beginning of our careers. Say “yes” to internships and clerkships and law review to maximize your career options. Say “yes” to billing more hours, taking clients to dinner, spending late nights at the office, and agreeing to tight deadlines so you can make partner and make more money. Say “yes” to your clients’ demands and requests whenever possible. But also, say “yes” to making healthy lunches for your kids, volunteering as a room mom for your kid’s class, keeping your children off of their screens, planning playdates and summer camps and after school activities so you don’t screw up your kids or look like a bad parent.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
It can be hard to say “no” — you don’t want to disappoint people, or lose out on opportunities, or feel judged for not doing enough. But if you don’t say “no” every once in a while, you’re letting other people’s invitations, requests, and demands dictate how you live your life.

Listen, mama: now is the time to be intentional about how you spend your time and your energy. Now is the time to choose your own adventure instead of letting everyone else choose it for you.

So how do you say “no” to the tyranny of yes?

First, realize that you are fully capable of saying “no.” We moms don’t hesitate to say “no” to protect our children from hot stoves, dangerous traffic, and cyberbullying. We do hesitate to say “no” to protect ourselves — our time, our peace, our health, our sanity — not because we can’t say “no” but because we don’t prioritize ourselves. It’s not that you can’t say “no,” it’s that you need to get comfortable with putting yourself first every once in a while.

If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Second, you must start listening to yourself. If you’ve spent years ignoring your own wants and needs, this will not be easy. You’ll need to block out time on your calendar for this — no, I’m not kidding. Block off 30 minutes a week to write down your goals, dreams, wants, and needs. (Be sure to turn off and step away from any distractions during this time. I promise the world will survive without your immediate attention for 30 minutes a week.) And start asking yourself what you want and what you need as a regular practice: at the grocery store, at the bookstore, when you’re choosing how to spend your weekend, when you’re deciding what to do for dinner, when you’re planning vacations.

Third, once you start listening to yourself, you can begin the process of aligning where you spend your time and your energy with your goals, dreams, wants, and needs. That way you’re not saying “no” to other people just to say “no” — you’re saying “no” to other people so you can say “yes” to yourself.

Fourth, be patient with yourself when you screw up. You can’t reverse decades of programming and practice in a few weeks or a few months. Start small, keep at it, and you’ll get better at it.

Fifth, be prepared for pushback. You and your partner, you and your kids, you and your parents, and you and your co-workers have been dancing together for a while (and you’ve probably been dancing backwards and in heels, because you’re a woman). When you start to change this dance by making your own moves and being less accommodating to your dance partner’s moves, he or she will feel unbalanced and uncomfortable. Your dance partner probably won’t be happy for you, at least not at first. They may get angry. They may turn up the guilt. But you have to stay strong. Remember that although giving in and going back to your old dance will feel easy and natural in the short-term, it is unsustainable in the long-term and will only lead to more resentment and bitterness.

Lastly, keep checking in with yourself. Keep listening to yourself. Keep saying “yes” to yourself.

Once you start learning to say “no” to the demands of other people, you will find more joy. You will become more true to yourself. You will be a better mother, a better partner, and a better attorney because you won’t be resentful, and you won’t be stretched beyond your limits. And you’ll discover that the people who truly love you don’t love you just because you’re always trying to make them happy; they love you because of who you are: a person who knows herself and knows her worth.

Eileen Lawrence opened her own estate planning practice in 2020, where she works with individuals, couples, and families. When Eileen is not practicing law, she enjoys spending time with her family, reading novels, writing poetry, and pretending to be a contestant on the Great British Baking Show. You can read more about her on her [website](http://centraltexaswills.com/) and contact her at eileen@eileenlawrencelaw.com.

# Am Law 100 Firm Furloughs Staff, No Other Cost-Cutting Measures For Now
## The firm hasn't made a decision on pay cuts.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onApril 13, 2020 at 2:41 PMApril 13, 2020 at 2:37 PM
15
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/am-law-100-firm-furloughs-staff-no-other-cost-cutting-measures-for-now/&text=Am%20Law%20100%20Firm%20Furloughs%20Staff,%20No%20Other%20Cost-Cutting%20Measures%20For%20Now)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/am-law-100-firm-furloughs-staff-no-other-cost-cutting-measures-for-now/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/am-law-100-firm-furloughs-staff-no-other-cost-cutting-measures-for-now/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The question of how, exactly, law firms should deal with the economic uncertainty surrounding COVID-19 remains an active one. While we’ve seen a range of responses from Biglaw, from [layoffs](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/am-law-100-firm-announces-associate-layoffs-and-other-cost-cutting-measures/), to [furloughs, ](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/biglaw-firm-furloughs-associates-firm-hopeful-they-can-return-to-work-soon/)and [associate salary cuts](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/another-am-law-100-firm-turns-to-furloughs-and-salary-cuts-amid-covid-19-crisis/), one of the more vexing question remains what to do with staff who are [dependent on physical locations to do their job](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/associates-take-a-20-percent-pay-cut-and-some-staff-gets-furloughed-at-this-am-law-100-firm/) and cannot work from home.

Sheppard Mullin, currently clocking in at [56th in the Am Law 200](https://www.law.com/law-firm-profile/?id=272&name=Sheppard-Mullin) ranking, just announced furloughs for a small amount of their staff. Those impacted are those that cannot work from home, and, in a statement from the firm, they’ve revealed staff members will continue to have medical benefits and will receive a bridge fund grant (funded by partners’ personal funds):

Sheppard Mullin today furloughed 33 of our 823 staff. We furloughed these team members because they cannot perform their jobs (such as receptionists, support services and file center employees) from home. These personnel have been on payroll through the four weeks of our Work From Home program. They have been told to expect to return to work in 60-90 days. Given the levels of unemployment insurance available, none of those furloughed will experience reduced compensation. During the furlough, Sheppard Mullin will pay for full medical benefits and will not require the furloughed employees to contribute to the insurance costs. In addition, because of the lag time between when an employee is furloughed and when unemployment benefits are received, partners and senior management have contributed personal funds to create a Bridge Fund to provide full equivalent take-home pay during the wait. These bridge funds are a grant, not a loan, and will not be paid back.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
And that’s it for austerity measures, at least for now. The firm says while layoffs are off the table, pay cuts or other measures haven’t been decided. The firm statement goes on:

Aside from the furlough of these staff members, we have made no other decisions regarding additional furloughs or a reduction in hours or compensation. We have no intention of doing any layoffs. Our goal is to treat all of the Sheppard Mullin family fairly and with consideration, while making sure we remain a strong firm.

If your firm or organization is slashing salaries, closing its doors, or reducing the ranks of its lawyers or staff, whether through open layoffs, stealth layoffs, or voluntary buyouts, please don’t hesitate to let us know. Our vast network of tipsters is part of what makes Above the Law thrive. You can [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Layoffs/Salary%20Cuts) or text us (646-820-8477).

If you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Layoff Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the layoff alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each layoff, salary cut, or furlough announcement that we publish.

# What You Need To Know About Compliance And Ethics In 2022
## Whether you’re in-house counsel, a compliance and ethics officer, a human resources executive, outside counsel, or a risk management consultant, ethics and compliance should be playing a critical role in your job responsibilities.
By Stephanie Wilkins  
onApril 22, 2022 at 3:16 PMApril 22, 2022 at 12:16 PM
4
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/04/what-you-need-to-know-about-compliance-and-ethics-in-2022/&text=What%20You%20Need%20To%20Know%20About%20Compliance%20And%20Ethics%20In%202022)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/04/what-you-need-to-know-about-compliance-and-ethics-in-2022/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/04/what-you-need-to-know-about-compliance-and-ethics-in-2022/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Many things go into the success of an organization, but staying on top of ethics and compliance is one of the most critical factors to remaining in business. Whether you’re in-house counsel, a compliance and ethics officer, a human resources executive, outside counsel, or a risk management consultant, ethics and compliance should be a priority.

In an increasingly tough regulatory environment, it’s important to implement an effective compliance program now. Among other things, your program should focus on increased accountability and transparency.

PLI’s intensive, two-day program, [Compliance & Ethics Essentials 2022](https://www.pli.edu/programs/compliance--ethics-essentials?t=live&p=331967?tCode=CNS2_ATL01&utm_source=ATL01&utm_medium=DISPLAY&utm_campaign=CNS2), brings together experts from major corporations, academia, law firms, and the government to review and discuss the  most critical issues in compliance and ethics this year, including:

- How to design and conduct effective compliance risk assessments for your organization
- How to structure your compliance and ethics program in order to achieve the right level of independence and authority
- The evolving role of your board
- The role of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues in your compliance program
- How you can use data analytics to improve your program
- Encouraging the reporting and investigation of allegations of wrongdoing at your organization
- The current best practices in compliance codes, communications, training, and tools
- Key ethics issues for compliance professionals
Regardless of your experience with compliance and ethics, the PLI’s faculty will share the knowledge you need to improve your program, increase employee awareness and decrease legal risk. Experts will share critical insights on  best practices and real-life experience with compliance in today’s corporate environment in order to help you identify and mitigate legal risks.

An effective compliance program is no longer just “nice-to-have” – it’s a necessity. [Register today](https://www.pli.edu/programs/compliance--ethics-essentials?t=live&p=331967?tCode=CNS2_ATL01&utm_source=ATL01&utm_medium=DISPLAY&utm_campaign=CNS2) to learn more.

# This Biglaw Firm Is At The Top Of The Billing Game
## That's a lot of hours.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onMay 10, 2019 at 5:17 PMMay 10, 2019 at 12:46 PM
12
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/05/this-biglaw-firm-is-at-the-top-of-the-billing-game/&text=This%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Is%20At%20The%20Top%20Of%20The%20Billing%20Game)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/05/this-biglaw-firm-is-at-the-top-of-the-billing-game/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/05/this-biglaw-firm-is-at-the-top-of-the-billing-game/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
According to data collected for the 2019 Am Law 100, which Am Law 100 firm billed the most hours (across all its attorneys) in 2018?

Hint: Obviously, firms with a larger headcount have an advantage in this category. This firm billed 6,641,414 hours in 2018.

See the answer on the next page.

# At Long Last, ‘The Reference Manual Of Legal Tech Lists’ Is Here! 
## From networking at trade shows to having fun outside of work, this volume details what you *really* need to know about the legal tech world.
By [Above the Law](https://abovethelaw.com/author/above-the-law/)  
onMay 5, 2023 at 12:17 PMMay 5, 2023 at 11:59 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/at-long-last-the-reference-manual-of-legal-tech-lists-is-here/&text=At%20Long%20Last,%20‘The%20Reference%20Manual%20Of%20Legal%20Tech%20Lists’%20Is%20Here! )[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/at-long-last-the-reference-manual-of-legal-tech-lists-is-here/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/at-long-last-the-reference-manual-of-legal-tech-lists-is-here/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
On the list of professions that love lists, lawyers take the top spot.

From Am Law to Vault to Chambers to US News … the list, it goes on.

No other industry has such a fixation on rankings, indexes, directories, and every manner of ordinally organized information.

Why not legal tech?

Today, in partnership with our friends at Wolters Kluwer, we’re pleased to present our brand new “Reference Manual of Legal Tech Lists.”

We’ve brought together some of the top voices in legal technology to bring you this often-lighthearted introduction to the capabilities, benefits, and quirks of the legal tech world.

From networking at trade shows to having fun outside of work, this volume details what you *really* need to know about the legal tech world.

We hope this eBook will help you meet all of your business goals — while providing a few laughs along the way. 

Fill out the form below to download your copy of the complete “Reference Manual of Legal Tech Lists.”

####Topics
[Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/biglaw/), [In-House Counsel](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/in-house-counsel/), [Legal Technology](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/legal-technology/), [Small Law Firms](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/small-law-firms-topic/), [Sponsored Content](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/sponsored-content/), [Technology](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/technology/), [Wolters Kluwer Lists](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/wolters-kluwer-lists/)
